But in order to do that, there seems to always be layoffs going on. Always.

pros: Friendly environment, great work atmosphere.
cons: No cons to talk about.

pros: I love my students. I love making a difference in their lives.
cons: Many departments in the school are adapting to market conditions rather than addressing curricular issues based on human needs. Some departments teach nothing but skills (that will be obsolete by the time students graduate). "The market" says students need job skills. There are job training programs out there that cost a lot less than a Bachelor's degree. What students need are humanities and liberal arts. They need to be able to read, write, and think critically. Such students will always excel -- in their lives as well as their jobs.

review_title: Could be better, could be worse
pros: The culture of the university is very relaxed (similar to most universities). The people that I work with are relatable and generally kind people.
cons:
This job was created to help assist the Financial Aid and Student Accounts offices during peak times of registration, payments, and processing paperwork. Unfortunately, the organization between offices is sub-par (to be polite) and there is a revolving door in many top leadership positions.

Whenever the university has the opportunity to turn things around by hiring a stellar candidate or allowing employees to provide creative solutions, they always seem to find the absolute best way to mess it up and ignore the needs and ideas of employees - in several departments.

job_title: Human Resources Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: Free outpatient mental health coverage through the medical plan, social justice mission, University President
cons: Failing financially, no work-life balance, lack of training, managers that don't care, managers that lack interest in their employees. .

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Chicago, IL
pros: Our new President has made a huge difference at Roosevelt and the University has noticed tremendous improvements.  Morale is better than it’s been in years.  Faculty and staff are happier with the new President and our student applications for next year are at an all-time high.
cons: It took several years for the old President to cause some of the issues the university is having, and it is going to take some time for the new President to clean up the mess left behind, but positive changes are obvious and very welcome.

review_title: RU is a hidden jewel in a big city.
pros: Naturally if you enjoy teaching in an urban setting, it is difficult to beat Michigan Avenue in Chicago. Being in the south loop provides you with an extended classroom and allows you to take advantage of the rich cultural opportunities that the city offers. Chicago is a much more manageable major city than say, New York. Roosevelt is a small university which makes it easy to get to know the rest of the faculty. The retirement package (401k) is among the best I've seen, and the health care (Blue Cross HMO) is reasonable.
cons: The commute can wear on you if you choose not to live in the city. Of course living in the south loop can be expensive.

pros: Great people to work with; welcoming environment
cons: HR office not very responsive to employee questions. Challenge in getting timely answers. Lack of communication starts at the top of this office and unfortunately does not look to improve.

pros: I work at the Schaumburg campus, and everyone there has a passion for what they do.  They have hired outside consultants who are trying to turn things around, but it's slow going.
cons: Administrators haven't had a pay raise for five years.  Although there have been many opportunities to give our input in what needs to be done to turn things around, our suggestions have been ignored.  As staff leave and no one replaces them, those who are left are being asked to take on additional work.  New hires have expressed how easily they are being burned out.  There is a lack of communication throughout the university that affects staff morale.

pros: There are very few reasons to work at Roosevelt University.
cons:
The entire ruling hierarchy of the university (President, Provost, Deans, administrators, administrative staff, and Trustees) has adopted a free-market view of education. Collegiality is gone. Shared governance is reduced to kabuki theater. Administrators see themselves as "management," and faculty as "labor." Labor is seen as an expense, and replaceable. Education is seen as a "service," and the University as a "service provider." 

Roosevelt is now selling a product on a market, and this "business model" has been damaging the "product," which used to be called a liberal education. Curricula have suffered from the demands of creating new, saleable programs and courses, "flavors of the day." Students have been enrolled who are looking for this kind of "product."

review_title: Lots of positives, just as many negatives
pros:
The leadership was very supportive of professional development opportunities. They're willing to allow employees to pursue conferences and webinars if the money was there.

The leadership has a big dreams, and they are come from the right place. It's inspiring if you buy into the mission.
cons:
The school is growing rapidly, but without the infrastructure to support such efforts. Student services has not expanded at a rate to support the growing student body. A good portion of the student body requires remedial support services, and there aren't enough going around.

A fair amount of croneyism exists at the top. It's disappointing that even with leadership turnover, a lot of dysfunction persists.

review_title: Good colleagues, great possibility, poor wages, inconsistent leadership
pros: Great colleagues dedicated to serving students. Many of these faculty and staff successfully create amazing teaching and learning experiences for students. Administrators allow workers the freedom to innovate and create as they wish.
cons: Lack of resources and inconsistent leadership means that even successful programs and learning opportunities come and go. Faculty and staff burn out is high. Innovation is expected but is often not sufficiently supported. Wages have been stagnate for years. Incompetence and poor planning have led to budget deficits.

review_title: High work performance expectations and low low salaries.
pros: Location:  In the loop and easy to get to from anywhere in the city.
cons: As a salary employee, they expect you to work outside of your job description to make up for slacking union employees and tenured professors, which leads to much overtime, but the salary is way below national averages and they do not provide raises in pay.  However, the president grants himself unrealistically high raises.  When I left he was somewhere around $650k while employees at my level hadn't had a raise in 6 years and could barely make ends meet.

review_title: My experience at Roosevelt has been interesting to say the least.
pros: The mission at Roosevelt always has the potential to change the world and already has. The benefits are top notch, especially the 12% [of your salary] retirement benefit and 100% tuition reimbursement for you and your dependents.
cons: Decisions seem to be made without looking at the big picture. Basic student services such as registration and financial aid have suffered as a result of elimination of support positions.

pros: Very few; I love my students and they appreciate my classes.
cons: Like most institutions of higher ed in the US, RU is top-heavy with redundant -- and highly paid -- administrators (who see themselves as "management"). Trying to impose a business model on a school is bad educational leadership. If the institution is in financial trouble (which it is) it is not because the faculty and staff are overpaid or underworked. Too much poorly planned, unsustainable "expansion" and building under last President; current President (by all accounts a smart and nice guy) may be in over his head.

pros: Great supervisor and coworkers with a relaxing atmosphere, One of those jobs in which your excited to go to work to every day
cons: Students are sometimes a hassle when they come to help at the end of the semester and expect to be taught everything from the beginning of the term in 1 hr.

job_title: Associate Professor Counselor Education in Chicago, IL
pros: I love what I do and RU is very supportive with respect to community engagement and transformational learning experiences for students. I work with amazing colleagues and have been allowed to create new and exciting classes and learning experiences for my students.
cons: VERY top heavy with respect to salary and compensation. While faculty and staff have had pay raises frozen for the last six years, the president, CFO, and other top administration took not only way over average salaries, but astronomical bonuses for "merit".

pros: Roosevelt University has made tremendous progress over the past decade.  It is investing over $100 million in a brand new building to improve the learning experience for it's students.  The university has focused on hiring only the best faculty from very prestigous programs.
cons: Some employees who are resistant to change are uncomfortable with the dramatic rate of improvements and the increased job responsibilities and expectations of performance.

pros: it was an exiting position and experience working with students and learning .  it is very flexible depending on the supervisor.
cons: there are not many negative aspects. the pay was not  as good as i wished it was. very little contact with administration and this is because it a student position . overall everything was very good specially if one enjoy working with student and doing research

review_title: The Single Worst Experience of my Career
pros: Location. It's on the upper edge of the South Loop, so it makes it easy to meet your friends after work for a MUCH needed drink.
cons:
Oh how I wish I had done my research before going to work at this hell hole.

There is a serious bully culture that is encouraged within the university. Not just with the students, although it's atrocious how the athletes are protected as they spew out homophobic, racist, and sexist propaganda on a nearly daily basis. The environment is riddled with "degree-poor" students who are too busy getting high openly in common areas INSIDE the buildings with nothing more than a slap on the wrist to ever be successful (try googling the last successful alumnus. You'll only get Shel Silverstein who was a drop out). These students are paying an astronomical amount of money to graduate and be losers.

The bully culture is also extremely heavy within the administration. Blatantly racist administrative decisions (see ANY people of color in Director or VP roles? No. They either all quit because of the racially hostile work environment, or were fired based on discriminatory reasons.  One high level VP was even humiliated and fired in an open letter from the president to the university.   And if you dare to question the direction of the university, prepare to be iced out and have your budgets frozen the next year.

The pay ranges are disgusting. There has not been an increase in salary - not even cost of living in more than 6 years! There are secretaries who make more than some management staff because they are protected by the union which ensures a raise annually.  Oh but Chuck Middleton gets a raise every year. As well as the CFO and the Provosts.  But the rest of the minions need to get back on the bread lines to make ends meet on an RU salary.

pros: Great students and colleagues, all focused on the mission of social justice
cons: It has been difficult to continue to work in the city when there are no wage increases. I am relatively new to the university, but it is my understanding that most positions have not seen an increase in over five years.

job_title: Biology and Chemistry Tutor in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Flexible scheduling, easy work, get to help your peers, funded via a grant, excellent supervisors, get to work closely with professors and develop a mentor-like relationship with them
cons: The pay is low but it is better than min wage, sometimes working with other students can be tough and they sometimes do not really want to do the work to understand the material

pros: Good students - RU has a diverse student body and most students seem eager to learn; great Chicago location; helpful department chairs; good HR dept.
cons: Timeliness of assigned classes - you find out too late; not quite sure if criteria to assign adjuncts to courses is consistent; awful Schaumburg campus (and students are quite different).

review_title: I worked as a Math tutor in the Academic Success Center. Great place to study and work.

cons: In my opinion the job job paid well and it was very rewarding. No Cons

pros:

-Everything is mostly in one building so you never have to go outside.
cons: -The debt of the University due to the Wabash building has put raises on hold for several years.

Business slows in the afternoon resulting in early release.

cons: The students who attend RU are not very engaged, so a lot of times my work doesn't feel like it matters.
